errors.title: Not a Git Repository
errors.meaning: This folder is not being tracked by Git. Either you need to initialize a new repository, or you're in the wrong folder.
errors.why: You're running a Git command in a folder that hasn't been set up with Git yet, or you navigated away from your project folder.
fixes: # If you want to start a new repository:
# If you cloned a project, make sure you're inside it:
# To find where your Git projects are:
# Look for folders containing a .git subfolder

errors.title: Detached HEAD State
errors.meaning: You are not on any branch - you're looking at a specific commit directly. Any new commits you make might be lost when you switch branches.
errors.why: This happens when you checkout a specific commit, tag, or remote branch directly instead of a local branch.
fixes: # To go back to your main branch (safest option):
# To keep your current changes in a new branch:
# To see what branch you were on before:
errors.warning: If you made commits in detached HEAD state, create a branch first or you may lose your work!

errors.title: Merge Conflict
errors.meaning: Git found changes in both your branch and the branch you're merging that modify the same lines of code. Git can't decide which version to keep, so you need to decide manually.
errors.why: Two people (or you on different branches) edited the same part of the same file. This is normal in collaborative development.
fixes: # Step 1: See which files have conflicts:
# Step 2: Open each conflicted file. Look for these markers:
# Step 3: Edit the file to keep the code you want
# Step 4: Mark as resolved and commit:

errors.title: Push Rejected (Non-Fast-Forward)
errors.meaning: The remote repository has commits that you don't have locally. Git rejected your push to prevent you from accidentally overwriting those commits.
errors.why: Someone else pushed changes to this branch after you last pulled, or you force-pushed from another machine.
fixes: # If there are conflicts, resolve them
errors.warning: NEVER use 'git push --force' unless you fully understand the consequences. It can permanently delete other people's work!

patterns: The current branch .* has no upstream
errors.title: No Upstream Branch
errors.meaning: Your local branch isn't connected to any remote branch. Git doesn't know where to push your changes.
errors.why: This is a new branch that you created locally, or the upstream tracking was never set up.
fixes: # Set up tracking and push in one command:
# For example, if your branch is called 'main':
# After this, regular 'git push' will work

patterns: Could not read from remote repository
errors.title: Permission Denied / Authentication Failed
errors.meaning: GitHub/GitLab/your Git server couldn't verify your identity. Your SSH key might be missing, expired, or not added to your account.
errors.why: SSH authentication failed. This could be because your key isn't set up, isn't added to the ssh-agent, or isn't registered with the remote service.
fixes: # Check if you have SSH keys:
# Generate a new SSH key if needed:
# Start ssh-agent and add your key:
# Copy your public key and add to GitHub/GitLab:
# Go to GitHub → Settings → SSH Keys → New SSH Key

errors.title: Branches Have Diverged
errors.meaning: Your local branch and the remote branch both have commits that the other doesn't have. They've gone in different directions.
errors.why: Changes were pushed to the remote from somewhere else while you were making local commits.
fixes: # Option 1: Merge remote changes into yours:
# Option 2: Rebase your commits on top of remote (cleaner):

errors.title: Rebase In Progress
errors.meaning: You started a rebase operation but it's not finished yet. Git is waiting for you to resolve conflicts or continue.
errors.why: A rebase was started (possibly with git pull --rebase) and encountered a situation that needs your input.
fixes: # If you've fixed the conflicts, continue:
# To skip the current problematic commit:
# To abort and go back to how things were:
errors.warning: If you're confused, 'git rebase --abort' is always safe - it undoes the rebase completely.

patterns: fatal: 'origin' does not appear to be a git repository
errors.title: No Remote Repository Configured
errors.meaning: Your local repository isn't connected to any remote repository like GitHub or GitLab.
errors.why: You initialized a new repository locally with 'git init' but haven't added a remote yet.
fixes: # First, create a repository on GitHub/GitLab
# Then add it as a remote:

patterns: Please commit your changes or stash them
errors.title: Uncommitted Changes Would Be Overwritten
errors.meaning: You have changes that aren't committed yet, and the operation you're trying to do would overwrite them.
errors.why: Git is protecting your work. It won't let you switch branches or pull if it would erase your uncommitted changes.
fixes: # Do your operation, then get them back:
errors.warning: Option 3 will permanently delete your uncommitted changes!

patterns: untracked working tree files would be overwritten
errors.title: Untracked Files Would Be Overwritten
errors.meaning: You have new files that aren't tracked by Git, and the operation would create files with the same names.
errors.why: The branch you're switching to has files that conflict with files you've created locally.
fixes: # Option 1: Add and commit the files:
# Option 2: Remove or rename the conflicting files
# This will delete your untracked files!
errors.warning: Make sure you don't need those files before forcing the operation!

errors.title: Nothing to Commit
errors.meaning: There are no changes staged for commit. Either you haven't modified any files, or you haven't added them to the staging area.
errors.why: You tried to commit but didn't run 'git add' first, or all your changes are already committed.

patterns: fatal: A branch named .* already exists
errors.title: Branch Already Exists
errors.meaning: You're trying to create a branch with a name that's already being used.
errors.why: Either you already created this branch before, or someone else did.
fixes: # Switch to the existing branch instead:
# Or create a branch with a different name:
# To delete the old branch (if you really want to recreate it):

errors.title: Cherry-Pick Conflict or Empty
errors.meaning: The commit you're trying to cherry-pick either conflicts with your current code or has already been applied.
errors.why: Cherry-picking applies a specific commit to your branch, but the changes conflict or already exist.
fixes: # If there are conflicts, resolve them, then:
# If the cherry-pick is empty (already applied):

errors.title: Lock File Exists
errors.meaning: A Git process didn't finish cleanly and left a lock file behind. This prevents other Git operations.
errors.why: A previous Git command crashed or was interrupted, or another Git process is still running.
fixes: # First, make sure no other Git process is running
errors.warning: Only delete lock files if you're sure no other Git operations are running!

patterns: this exceeds GitHub's file size limit
errors.title: Large Files Detected
errors.meaning: You're trying to push files that exceed the size limit (usually 100MB for GitHub).
errors.why: Large binary files, datasets, or build artifacts were added to the repository.
fixes: # Option 1: Remove the large file from tracking:
# Option 2: Use Git LFS for large files:
git commit -m "Track large files with LFS"
# If already committed, you may need to rewrite history:
errors.warning: Rewriting history affects everyone who has cloned the repo!

errors.title: Shallow Clone Limitation
errors.meaning: You have a shallow clone (partial history) and the operation requires full history.
errors.why: The repository was cloned with --depth to save space/time, but now you need the full history.

errors.title: Submodule Issue
errors.meaning: There's a problem with Git submodules in this repository.
errors.why: Submodules are repositories inside repositories. They need to be initialized and updated separately.
fixes: # Or do both in one command:

errors.title: Clean Working Tree Required
errors.meaning: This operation requires no uncommitted changes in your working directory.
errors.why: Operations like 'git stash pop' or some merges need a clean state to work safely.
